snippet: The shootings at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin shined a light on “hatecore” and an obscure cultural scene that is helping keep the white supremacist movement energized.
abstract: Shootings at Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis, by white supremacist Wade M Page that killed six people shines a light on an obscure cultural scene, and white power music known as 'hatecore', that is helping keep the white supremacist movement energized; Southern Poverty Law Center data shows movement, which has grown sharply, is more decentralized and disorganized than ever.

byline.original: By JAMES DAO and SERGE F. KOVALESKI
byline.contributor: James Dao reported from Milwaukee, and Serge F. Kovaleski from Denver. James C. McKinley Jr. and Ben Sisario contributed reporting from New York, and Scott Shane from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The shootings at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin shined a light on “hatecore” and an obscure cultural scene that is helping keep the white supremacist movement energized.

headline.seo: Hatecore Music Is Called White Supremacist Recruiting Tool
headline.main: Music Style Is Called Supremacist Recruiting Tool
headline.print_headline: Music Style Is Called Supremacist Recruiting Tool
